title: Secretary of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (Australia)
text:
The Secretary of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet is the <a href="Australian%20Public%20Service">public service</a> <a href="Departmental%20secretary">head</a> of Australia's <a href="Department%20of%20the%20Prime%20Minister%20and%20Cabinet%20%28Australia%29">Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet</a> and the most senior <a href="public%20servant">public servant</a> in the administration of <a href="Government%20of%20Australia">Government in Australia</a>.
The Secretary of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet should not be confused with the <a href="Cabinet%20Secretary%20%28Australian%20minister%29">Cabinet Secretary</a>, a ministerial position within the <a href="Department%20of%20the%20Prime%20Minister%20and%20Cabinet%20%28Australia%29">Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet</a> portfolio responsible for assisting the <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Australia">Prime Minister</a> in the procedural and operational matters of the <a href="Cabinet%20of%20Australia">Cabinet of Australia</a>.
The Secretary of the DPMC is Australia’s highest-paid bureaucrat, earning more than $914,000, as of 2019.

Historical arrangements.
Within days of <a href="John%20Gorton">John Gorton</a> becoming Prime Minister, the functions of the Prime Minister's Department was split and a Department of the Cabinet Office was established. On taking office as Prime Minister in 1971, <a href="William%20McMahon">William McMahon</a> reversed Gorton's changes and restored earlier changes via the creation of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. A lesser role of Secretary to the Department of the Vice-President of the Executive Council was established for a short time; abolished in the early days of the <a href="Whitlam%20government">Whitlam government</a>. Upon <a href="1996%20Australian%20federal%20election">election to office in 1996</a>, <a href="John%20Howard">John Howard</a> established a separate <a href="Cabinet%20of%20Australia">Cabinet Office</a> within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The Cabinet Office was a small unit, staffed from within and outside the public service, which provided the Prime Minister with advice on issues before Cabinet as well as strategic policy directions.
